Award.AwardTitle: The functional ecology of an adaptive radiation: stable isotopes, niches, phylogenies and kidneys
Award.AbstractNarration: Despite their status as the most diverse lineage of birds and their occupation of nearly every terrestrial habitat on the planet, songbirds (passerines, or perching birds) have rarely adapted to become marine specialists. The paucity of marine species among passerines is probably due to the absence of functional salt glands and to the relative inability of bird kidneys to produce highly concentrated urine, which prevents them from coping with the salt loads that accompany marine resources. This project will track the evolutionary pathways that led to a marine niche in an evolutionary radiation of a group of South American songbirds in which two species have independently become marine specialists. The group also includes freshwater specialists and species that occupy both freshwater and marine habitats. We will also investigate the physiological mechanisms that facilitated the transition from a freshwater to a marine environment. Achieving these objectives demands three complementary approaches: 1) using molecular techniques to elucidate the evolutionary relationship among the species in the group; 2) using stable isotopes to quantify the relative reliance of each of these species on marine resources, and 3) using physiological and morphological measurements to assess the traits that allow marine species to cope with the salt loads that accompany the use of marine resources. This project is fundamentally interdisciplinary and hence its participants include a physiologist, a phylogenetic systematist, and a statistician. The project is also an international collaboration that includes scientists from Chile and Brazil. Expeditionary physiology aims to explore the planet's functional biodiversity, and this project is an ideal instrument for communicating biology and inspiring young scholars. This project is a collaboration with elementary and middle school teachers across Wyoming to develop classroom exercises and interactive, web-based, virtual expeditions in order to make the research accessible to their students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project was guided by several general questions that are best motivated by first describing the system that we investigated. We studied a group of South American birds with remarkable variation in ecological habits. Of the 16 species in this group, two species live by the ocean in the shores of one of the driest deserts and feed like shorebirds on marine organisms. They appear to be the most marine of all perching birds. Until we conducted our research, it was a mystery how they coped with the absence of water and with a salty diet. Several species inhabit the highest mountains in the Andes, and others appear to migrate seasonally between the high Andes and lower elevations. One species is found only in remote islands of the South Atlantic. Researchers had hypothesized that these species represent an adaptive radiation, meaning that they share a common ancestor, that they diversified rapidly into a variety of “niches”, and that their diversification was accompanied by traits that are well suited to these niches. We aimed to test this idea. The species that we chose to study are fascinating because they are very diverse ecologically, but they are very poorly known because they live in remote areas. We investigated these birds using the stable isotope composition of their tissues both from birds captured in the field and from the many specimens that have been deposited through the years in museum collections. We also studied their morphological and physiological characteristics in museums and the field.

 

Stable isotopes are forms of an element that vary in their atomic weight but not in atomic number. Our research hinged on three observations: 1) the isotopic composition of the birds’ tissues reflects that of the food that they eat and of the water that they drink (we tested this conjecture in the laboratory); 2) the isotopic composition of carbon and nitrogen varies among food webs and we can distinguish among resources that come from terrestrial, marine, and island food webs; 3) the isotopic composition of the water and resources used by birds varies with elevation. We gathered a very large sample of feathers of these birds from museum speciments and tissues from birds caught in the filed and analyzed their isotopic composition. We found that we could characterize not only the food webs that these birds relied on, but also estimate the elevation in the Andes where the birds grew the feather. In addition, our data allowed us to find out whether birds depended on only one or on many types of food webs, and whether they occupied narrow or broad altitudinal ranges in the mountains of the Andes. Two of the species that we studied proved to be remarkable in that their tissues were almost completely comprised of resources derived from marine environments –they were indeed the most marine of all songbirds.

 

When we investigated the species with broad use of food webs and broad elevational distributions in the field, we found that these species varied seasonally in the use of food webs because they migrated from high to low elevations. Their feathers had the isotopic value of food webs high in the Andes, where they molted those feathers, but their blood had the composition of the lowland food webs where they spent the winter. By using tissues that are deposited and that remain inert, and tissues that change their isotopic composition, we were able to determine seasonal changes in the use of resources and geographical areas in individuals.

When we mapped our results unto an evolutionary tree of all the species, we discovered how niches evolved. We found that the marine habit evolved only once and with it evolved the ability to conserve water and cope with salt that results from having kidneys that are able to make very concentrated urine.
